content:
Apologies if this is answered somewhere--my searches didn't turn up anything. I like the angle bracket syntax for Sigma pairs, but nearly all of the fonts I have installed make them look almost like parentheses unless I make the font size very large. (The exception among the fonts I have is horribly ugly.)

(I'm using lean.nvim with neovim running in a gui front end, Goneovim, but I imagine I would be able to use many fixed-width fonts.)

Since it appears that readily distinguishable angle brackets is not a priority for many fixed-width fonts, I'd be interested in any suggestions you have. I'm not using a lot of Unicode, but who knows in the future, so doing well with other math symbols is obviously a plus. "Font with easily distinguishable angle brackets" is not a useful web search string. :-)
Sorry--I found the solution in a question on a partially related topic: JetBrains Mono is perfect. I had to try it out to realize that.
mars0i has marked this topic as resolved.
I use Iosevka and they look great there

People here have mentioned Julia Mono, which I find to be great for Lean. I only use it for Lean (i.e. I use a different editor for Lean than everything else), so I can't speak to how it looks for anything else.

Thanks @Max Nowak üêâ, @llllvvuu. Good to have additional options--I've installed both now. I agree about Iosevka's angle brackets. In my editor at my normal font size, the angle brackets in JuliaMono aren't as distinguishable as I'd like, but I might use it for something else. I figured out yesterday that I can set a different font for Lean in vim/neovim using e.g. autocmd filetype lean set guifont=JetBrains\ Mono\ NL:h13.
